Award.AwardTitle: Heterogeneous Catalysts Tailored for Parahydrogen Induced Nuclear Spin Polarization
Award.AbstractNarration:
With support from the Chemical Measurement and Imaging Program in the Division of Chemistry, Professors Bowers and Hagelin-Weaver and their groups at the University of Florida will combine state-of-the-art catalyst synthesis, characterization, and reaction studies to identify and mitigate the processes that reduce pairwise hydrogenation during Parahydrogen Induced Polarization (PHIP). PHIP is a robust and inexpensive method used for sensitivity enhanced nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) spectroscopy and magnetic resonance imaging. In addition to potential biomedical utilization, PHIP is a powerful method for the study of hydrogenation catalysis and new insights gained during this proposed research may well have a major impact on the field of catalytic reactions, beyond hydrogenation. Students will receive interdisciplinary training in catalysis, reactor design, materials characterization, and surface chemistry. The PIs also propose to reach out to teachers from rural and urban schools serving 50% or more students from socio-economically underserved homes by coordinating with UF's CPET programs for teacher recruitment. The proposed outreach efforts will provide an innovative and productive linkage between cutting-edge research and secondary school STEM education.

The proposed research seeks to identify correlations between catalyst properties, activity and pairwise selectivity. The proposed research plan will be the first to combine state-of-the art nanoparticle fabrication strategies with precision atomic layer deposition (ALD). Interpretation of PHIP data will be guided by spin density matrix theory. Development of unique PHIP NMR instrumentation is another key element of the project. Pairwise selectivities obtained with oxides and oxide supported metal particles are currently limited to a few percent. Attaining substantially higher pairwise selectivity using engineered oxide-supported metal nanoparticle catalysts would be a transformative outcome of the project. This low pairwise selectivity problem will be addressed through fundamental kinetic and mechanistic studies. The proposed studies also aim to broaden the variety of targets that can be hyperpolarized by this class of catalyst.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) spectroscopy utilizes radio wave pulses and high magnetic fields to probe the chemical environment of magnetic nuclei in molecules and materials. NMR techniques are crucial for research in many fields of science and medicine. However, conventional NMR suffers from low sensitivity due to the weak interaction between the magnetic nuclei and the magnetic field. Hence, NMR signals tend to be small and difficult to measure which is problematic for many applications including medical magnetic resonance imaging (MRI). This project involves the tailoring of heterogeneous catalyst materials for parahydrogen enhanced NMR. In this method, the NMR-invisible quantum order inherent to the parahydrogen molecule is used to align the nuclear magnetic moments in a target substrate molecule, which affords signal amplifications of up to 10,000x (in theory). The outcomes of the project include: synthesis of novel oxide-supported metal nanoparticle hydrogenation catalysts with nanoparticle sizes, compositions, and particle-support interactions that maximize the PHIP signal enhancement;  development of advanced catalyst synthesis protocols; new insight into the spin-dynamics in catalytic intermediates and surface interactions; record high NMR signal amplification of up to 2000x. More specifically, we

  • Elucidated transition states in heterogeneous hydrogenation catalysis – mechanism of hydrogenation over CeO2 is different for alkene and alkynes.
  • Identified the Pt-Sn intermetallic nanoparticles as a catalytic platform for highly selective pairwise addition and related the high selectivity to the surface structure and composition
  • Demonstrated the preparation of hyperpolarized metabolites by heterogeneous hydrogenation in aqueous solution
  • Demonstrated that strong-metal support interactions (SMSI) can enhance the pairwise selectivity of hydrogenation
  • Showed that shaped ceria nanoparticles exhibit varying selectivity and activity depending on surface facet structure
  • Obtained initial results demonstrating the high atom efficiency and high pairwise selectivity of atomically dispersed platinum on ceria prepared by atomic layer deposition.

The heterogeneous catalysis approach adopted in this project offers key benefits over solution-state PHIP using dissolved catalysts and could ultimately lead to widespread use for rapid and inexpensive preparation of pure hyperpolarized metabolic precursors for MRI detection and treatment of diseases like cancer. In this project, the PI and co-PI have asserted US leadership in this rapidly emerging field. Graduate and undergraduate students involved in this project have received training in catalysis, reactor design, materials characterization, surface chemistry, and NMR. The project has provided a key linkage between cutting-edge research and secondary school STEM education through the involvement of high-school students.
